Nanci_Griffith:
{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (1953–2021)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Nanci Griffith | image = Nanci Griffith at BBC Radio 2 Folk Awards 2010.jpg | caption = Griffith receiving an award at the [[BBC Radio 2]] Folk Awards in 2010 | image_size = | birth_name = Nanci Caroline Griffith | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1953|07|06}} | birth_place = [[Seguin, Texas]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|2021|08|13|1953|07|06}} | death_place = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S. | instrument = Vocals, acoustic guitar | genre = [[Country (music)|Country]], [[country folk]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[neotraditional country]] | years_active = 1977–2021 | label = [[B.F. Deal Records|B.F. Deal]], Featherbed, [[Philo Records (folk)|Philo]], [[MCA Records|MCA]], [[Elektra Records|Elektra]], [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], New Door | website = {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210225194609/http://www.nancigriffith.com/ |title=nancigriffith.com |date=February 25, 2021}} }} '''Nanci Caroline Griffith''' (July 6, 1953 – August 13, 2021) was an American singer, guitarist, and songwriter.{{cite book|title=The Virgin Encyclopedia of Popular Music|editor=Colin Larkin|editor-link=Colin Larkin (writer)|publisher=[[Virgin Books]]|date=1997|edition=Concise|isbn=1-85227-745-9|pages=548–9|title-link=Encyclopedia of Popular Music}} She often appeared on the [[PBS]] music program ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' starting in 1985 (season 10). In 1994 she won a [[Grammy Awards|Grammy Award]] for the album ''[[Other Voices, Other Rooms (Nanci Griffith album)|Other Voices, Other Rooms]].''{{Cite web|last=Sweeting|first=Adam|date=2021-08-15|title=Nanci Griffith obituary|url=http://www.theguardian.com/music/2021/aug/15/nanci-griffith-obituary|access-date=2021-08-15|website=The Guardian|language=en}} Griffith toured with various other artists including [[Buddy Holly]]'s band, [[the Crickets]]; [[John Prine]], [[Iris DeMent]], [[Suzy Bogguss]], [[Judy Collins]], and [[The Everly Brothers]].Steve Hochman: [https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1986-10-01-ca-3731-story.html '' Country Music’s Griffith Has A Few Novel Ideas''], latimes.com, Oct. 1, 1986 Griffith recorded duets with many artists, among them [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Mary Black]], [[John Prine|Prine]], [[Don McLean]], [[Jimmy Buffett]], [[Dolores Keane]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Adam Duritz]] (singer of [[Counting Crows]]), [[the Chieftains]], [[John Stewart (musician)|John Stewart]], and [[Darius Rucker]]. Griffith referred to her backing band as the Blue Moon Orchestra. ==Early life and career== Griffith, the youngest of three siblings, was born in [[Seguin, Texas]] and grew up in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], where her family moved shortly after her birth.[https://www.texasmonthly.com/arts-entertainment/nanci-griffith-more-loved-than-she-knew/ Nanci Griffith Was More Loved Than She Knew ], texasmonthly.com, August 16, 2021 Her mother Ruelene was a real estate agent and amateur actress; her father, Marlin Griffith, was a graphic artist and barbershop quartet singer.[https://www.globemediawire.com/world/2021/08/14/nanci-griffiths-death-grammy-winning-singer-dies-at-68/ Nanci Griffith’s death: Grammy-winning singer dies at 68 ], globemediawire.com, Aug 14, 2021[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/nanci-griffith-death-age-songs-b1902443.html Nanci Griffith: Grammy-winning singer dies aged 68], independent.co.uk, August 14, 2021. Griffith began her music career at age 12, singing in a local coffeehouse. When she was a teenager her father took her to see [[Townes Van Zandt]]. At 14, she performed her first professional gig at the Red Lion Cabaret in downtown Austin.[https://statesman.com/story/entertainment/music/2021/08/27/nanci-griffith-obituary-austin-singer-songwriter-dead/8188421002/ ''Remembering Nanci Griffith, the greatest Austin-raised singer-songwriter ever''], statesman.com, Aug 27, 2021 Her debut album, [[There's a Light Beyond These Woods|''There’s a Light Beyond These Woods'']], was released in 1978; the cover was designed by her father. Griffith's career spanned a variety of musical genres, predominantly [[country music|country]], [[folk music|folk]], and what she termed "folkabilly." She won a Grammy for [[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Folk Album|Best Contemporary Folk Album]] in 1994 for her 1993 recording, ''[[Other Voices, Other Rooms (Nanci Griffith album)|Other Voices, Other Rooms]].''{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-58212802|title=Nanci Griffith: Folk and country singer-songwriter dies aged 68|publisher=BBC|language=English|date=14 August 2021|access-date=16 August 2021}} The album features Griffith covering the songs of artists who were her major influences. One of her better-known songs is "[[From a Distance]]," which was written and composed by [[Julie Gold]]. Similarly, other artists have occasionally achieved greater success than Griffith herself with songs that she wrote or co-wrote. For example, [[Kathy Mattea]] had a country music top five hit with a 1986 cover of Griffith's "[[Love at the Five and Dime]]" and [[Suzy Bogguss]] had one of her largest hits with Griffith (and [[Tom Russell]])'s "[[Outbound Plane]]".{{citation needed|date=August 2021}} In 1994, Griffith teamed with [[Jimmy Webb]] to contribute the song "If These Old Walls Could Speak" to the [[AIDS]] benefit album ''[[Red Hot + Country]]'' produced by the [[Red Hot Organization]]. She survived [[breast cancer]] which was diagnosed in 1996, and [[thyroid cancer]] in 1998.{{cite web |url=http://www.nancigriffith.com/biography.php |title=Biography |access-date=January 13, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070113061945/http://www.nancigriffith.com/biography.php |archive-date=January 13, 2007 }} originating from nancigriffith.com Retrieved January 31, 2013{{cite news | url = https://www.irishtimes.com/culture/music/nanci-griffith-s-irish-hit-cancer-history-and-really-dysfunctional-family-1.4648298 | title = Nanci Griffith's Irish hit, cancer history and 'really dysfunctional' family | last = Sweeting | first = Adam | date = August 16, 2021 | newspaper = The Irish Times | access-date = July 9, 2022 | quote = She was diagnosed with breast cancer in 1996 and thyroid cancer in 1998.}} [[Christine Lavin]], a singer and songwriter, remembers the first time she saw Griffith perform:
I was struck by how perfect everything was about her singing, her playing, her talking. I realized from the get-go that this was someone who was a complete professional. Obviously she had worked a long time to get to be that good.Deitz, Roger (May/June 1995). "Home at Last". ''Acoustic Guitar''. No. 30. p. 52.
Griffith contributed background vocals on many other recordings.{{Cite web |url=http://www.grantguerrero.com/nanguest.html |title=Comprehensive Nanci Griffith Discography |access-date=September 5, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303181109/http://www.grantguerrero.com/nanguest.html |archive-date=March 3, 2016 |url-status=dead }} [[File:Nanci Griffith Cambridge Festival 2007 (966579201).jpg|260px|thumb|right|Griffith performing at the [[Cambridge Folk Festival]], 2007]] Griffith suffered from severe [[writer's block]] after 2004, lasting until the 2009 release of her ''[[The Loving Kind (Nanci Griffith Album)|The Loving Kind]]'' album, which contained nine selections that she had written and composed either entirely by herself or as collaborations."Her songs were an extension of her literary interests – she wrote long-form and short-form fiction that sometimes became songs, and vice versa – and when songs wouldn't come (she suffered from songwriter’s block between 2004 and 2009), she would use prose to try and keep the words flowing." [https://www.heraldscotland.com/news/19517475.obituary-nanci-griffith-grammy-winning-singer-songwriter/ ''Obituary: Nanci Griffith, Grammy-winning singer-songwriter''], by Rob Adams, heraldscotland.com, August 16th, 2021 After several months of limited touring in 2011, Griffith's bandmates [[The Kennedys (band)|the Kennedys]] ([[Pete & Maura Kennedy]]) packed up their professional [[Manhattan]] recording studio and moved it to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] installing it in Griffith's home. There with her backing group including the Kennedys and Pat McInerney, she co-produced her album ''[[Intersection (album)|Intersection]]'' over the summer. The album included several new original songs and was released in April 2012 on [[Proper Records]].{{cite web |url=http://www.proper-records.co.uk/artists/nanci-griffith |last=Griffith |first=Nanci |title=Intersection|website=Proper-records.co.uk|date=December 20, 2011 }} ==Awards== Griffith won the 1994 [[Grammy Award]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Folk Album|Best Contemporary Folk Album]] for ''[[Other Voices, Other Rooms (Nanci Griffith album)|Other Voices, Other Rooms]].'' She was inducted into the Austin Music Hall of Fame in 1995.[https://www.austinchronicle.com/daily/music/2021-08-13/powerful-folk-and-country-songwriter-nanci-griffith-has-died-at-age-68/ Powerfully Poetic Folk and Country Songwriter Nanci Griffith Has Died at Age 68], austinchronicle.com, Aug. 13, 2021 Griffith was awarded the Kate Wolf Memorial Award by the [[World Folk Music Association]] in 1995.{{Cite book|title=Number No. 1 : the story of the original Highwaymen|last=Noble|first=Richard E.|publisher=Outskirts Press|year=2009|isbn=9781432738099|location=Denver|pages=265–267|oclc=426388468}} In 2008, the [[Americana Music Association]] awarded her its Lifetime Americana Trailblazer Award."In 2008, the Americana Music Association gave her a Lifetime Americana Trailblazer Award." in: [https://www.nytimes.com/2021/08/13/arts/music/nanci-griffith-dead.html ''Nanci Griffith, Singer Who Blended Folk and Country, Dies at 68''], nytimes.com, Aug 13, 2021 [[Lyle Lovett]], who contributed backing vocals to her third album, ''[[Once in a Very Blue Moon]]'',"Doster played guitar on Griffith’s first album in 1978, and joined her in Nashville for her third, “Once In A Very Blue Moon,” six years later. By then, Griffith had a record deal with folk label Rounder, and a lot of friends and musical collaborators to call on. Her acoustic sound had been amped up a notch, with stalwart Nashville players like Béla Fleck, Roy Huskey Jr. and Mark O’Connor – and a lanky guy she knew from the Texas music scene named Lyle Lovett, singing harmony." in: [https://www.texasstandard.org/stories/remembering-nanci-griffith-she-was-just-a-good-good-good-songwriter/ ''Remembering Nanci Griffith: ‘She Was Just A Good, Good, Good Songwriter’''], by Shelly Brisbin, texasstandard.org, August 16, 2021 had won it before her. In 2010, Griffith received a Lifetime Achievement Award at [[BBC Radio 2 Folk Awards]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/folk/2010/02/lifetime-achievement-award-for.html ''Lifetime Achievement Award for Nanci Griffith''], bbc.co.uk, Feb 1, 2010 Griffith was inducted into the Texas Heritage Songwriters Association's Hall of Fame in February 2022 at the [[Paramount Theatre (Austin, Texas)|Paramount Theatre]] in Austin.[https://eu.austin360.com/story/entertainment/music/2021/08/27/nanci-griffith-obituary-austin-singer-songwriter-dead/8188421002/ ''Remembering Nanci Griffith, the greatest Austin-raised singer-songwriter ever''], by Peter Blackstock (Austin American-Statesman), austin360.com, Aug 27, 2021[https://musicrow.com/2021/05/lefty-frizzell-nanci-griffith-lightnin-hopkins-mark-james-to-join-texas-songwriters-hall-of-fame/ ''Lefty Frizzell, Nanci Griffith, Lightnin’ Hopkins, Mark James To Join Texas Songwriters Hall Of Fame''], musicrow.com, May 28, 2021[http://www.ntxe-news.com/cgi-bin/artman/exec/view.cgi?archive=85&num=124739 ''Texas Heritage Songwriters’ Association announces 2022 Hall of Fame inductees''], ntxe-news.com == The Blue Moon Orchestra == Griffith called her backing band the Blue Moon Orchestra. With regard to the chosen stage name, she wrote: {{Blockquote|During the Christmas holidays of 1986 I organized a band of musicians to work this road of touring and to pass effortlessly through mine fields of studio sessions. They chose their name, the Blue Moon Orchestra, from my third album, ''Once In A Very Blue Moon''. Some of them I had recorded and toured with prior to 1986: and some simply wandered into the Blue Moon Orchestra through this revolving open door of the road.|Nanci Griffith [https://web.archive.org/web/19970616135812/http://www.sover.net:80/~rschrull/ngriffith/gchpage.html in 1997]}} The title selection of the ''Once in a Very Blue Moon'' album reached number 85 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart in 1986."Griffith didn't write the title song from ''Once In A Very Blue Moon'', but she made the Pat Alger tune her own – so much so that the band she formed in the late 1980s, and toured with for 20 years, was called the Blue Moon Orchestra." in: [https://www.texasstandard.org/stories/remembering-nanci-griffith-she-was-just-a-good-good-good-songwriter/ "Remembering Nanci Griffith: 'She Was Just A Good, Good, Good Songwriter'"], by Shelly Brisbin, texasstandard.org, August 16, 2021"From that point on, Griffith named every band she fronted, big or small, the Blue Moon Orchestra. The clear desire, I assume, was to honor and recall that album's familial spirit. The core of the band stayed with her for the long haul." in: [https://artsfuse.org/236802/music-remembrance-singer-songwriter-nanci-griffith-1953-2021/ "Music Remembrance: Singer-songwriter Nanci Griffith (1953-2021)"], by Daniel Gewertz, artsfuse.org, September 14, 2021 In 1986, Griffith showcased tracks from her ''Lone Star State of Mind'' album on [[The Nashville Network]] TV show, ''New Country''. ;Final members * Nanci Griffith – lead vocals, guitar * Pat McInerney – drums, percussion * [[Maura Kennedy]] – vocals, guitar * [[Pete Kennedy]] – guitar, vocals ;Previous members * [[James Hooker (musician)|James Hooker]] – piano, [[Hammond B-3|B-3]], keyboards, vocals * Byrd Burton – guitar * [[Frank Christian (singer-songwriter)|Frank Christian]] – guitar * [[Philip Donnelly (musician)|Philip Donnelly]] – guitar * [[Danny Flowers]] – guitar * [[Clive Gregson]] – guitar, vocals * [[Thomm Jutz]] – guitar, vocals * Doug Lancio – electric guitar * Lee Satterfield – vocals, rhythm guitar, [[mandolin]] * Denny Bixby – bass, harmony vocals * Ron De La Vega – [[double bass|bass]], cello * Le Ann Etheridge – vocals, bass guitar, rhythm guitar * Pete Gordon – bass * Pete Gorisch – bass, cello * Danny Milliner – bass * J. T. Thomas – bass, vocals * Fran Breen – drums * Liam Genockey – drums * Steve Smith – drums ;Guest backing vocalists * [[Emmylou Harris]] * [[Iris DeMent]] * [[Lyle Lovett]] * Denice Franke"From those early Kerrville campfires to her angelic harmonizing with Nanci Griffith and that classic unreleased tape with Mickie Merkens...to crowded folk venues from Texas to Switzerland, Denice Franke's music has always moved me. She's a deeply talented writer, singer, and guitarist. One of Texas' finest." --- Tom Russell | Source: [http://www.denicefranke.com/presskit.html denicefranke.com] == Personal life == Griffith's high school boyfriend, John, died in a motorcycle accident after taking her to the senior prom. He inspired many of her later songs.{{cite web|url=http://popdose.com/the-popdose-guide-to-nanci-griffith/ |title=The Popdose Guide to Nanci Griffith |publisher=Popdose |date=January 8, 2008 |access-date=May 21, 2012}} She was married to singer-songwriter [[Eric Taylor (American musician)|Eric Taylor]] from 1976 to 1982. In the early 1990s, she was engaged to singer-songwriter [[Tom Kimmel]].{{Citation|last=Ibrahim|first=Samantha|title=Nanci Griffith, Grammy-winning 'Five and Dime' singer, dead at 68|newspaper=[[New York Post]]|date=August 13, 2021|url=https://nypost.com/2021/08/13/nanci-griffith-folk-singer-songwriter-dead-at-68/|access-date=August 14, 2021}} ==Death== Griffith died in Nashville on August 13, 2021, at the age of 68. The exact cause of death was not reported{{Cite web|last=Aswad|first=Jem|date=August 13, 2021|title=Nanci Griffith, Grammy-Winning Singer-Songwriter, Dies at 68|url=https://variety.com/2021/music/news/nanci-griffith-dead-dies-1235041416/|access-date=August 13, 2021|website=Variety|language=en-US}}''People magazine'' August 30th, 2021 issue Page 24 but her management company attributed it to natural causes.{{cite news |url=https://preview.houstonchronicle.com/music/texas-legend-singer-songwriter-nanci-griffith-16385452 |last=Dansby|first=Andrew|date=August 13, 2021|title=Texas legend and Grammy-winning folk singer-songwriter Nanci Griffith dies |newspaper=Houston Chronicle |access-date=December 30, 2022}} == Tribute album == On September 22, 2023, a tribute album, ''[[More than a Whisper: Celebrating the Music of Nanci Griffith]]'', was released by [[Rounder Records|Rounder]] and [[Concord Records]]. The compilation featured covers of Griffith's songs by her friends and fans including [[Sarah Jarosz]], [[John Prine]], [[Kelsey Waldon]], [[Billy Strings]], [[Molly Tuttle]], [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Lyle Lovett]], [[Kathy Mattea]], [[Brandy Clark]], [[Shawn Colvin]], Ida Mae, [[Steve Earle]], [[Aaron Lee Tasjan]], [[Todd Snider]], [[Iris DeMent]], [[Mary Gauthier]], and [[The War and Treaty]].{{cite news |url=https://www.stereogum.com/2237023/stream-the-new-nanci-griffith-tribute-album-feat-steve-earle-billy-strings-iris-dement-more/music/|last=Breihan|first=Tom|date=September 22, 2023|title=Stream The New Nanci Griffith Tribute Album Feat. Steve Earle, Billy Strings, Iris DeMent, & More|magazine=[[Stereogum]] |access-date=September 23, 2023}} == Biography == ''Love at the Five and Dime: The Songwriting Legacy of Nanci Griffith'' by author Brian T. Atkinson is scheduled for release through Texas A&M University Press on September 4, 2024. According to the author's website, ''Love at the Five and Dime'' includes forewords by the Indigo Girls, Lovett, Mattea, and more than one hundred thirty interviews with songwriter friends such as Earle, [[Rodney Crowell]] , [[Don McLean]], and followers like [[Elizabeth Cook]], the Counting Crows' Adam Duritz and [[Todd Snider]] as well as players like [[Lloyd Green]] and [[Tom Norris (musician)|Tom Norris]], a violinist with the [[London Symphony Orchestra]]. Interviews with producers Tony Brown, [[Peter Collins (record producer)|Peter Collins]] and [[Jim Rooney (music)|Jim Rooney]] are also in the book. ==Discography== === Studio albums === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" | Year ! rowspan="2" | Album ! colspan="3" | Peak chart positions ! rowspan="2" | Label |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! style="width:45px;" | [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]
